Buckler Parry

You may decide to parry incoming attacks with your Buckler or Light Shield. To parry the attack, make an attack roll as if you were performing a Shield Bash, including applicable attack bonuses. If your result is greater than the attacking creature's result, its attack automatically misses. You can parry as many attacks per turn as the number of attacks you would be able to make with your shield hand. 
You must make the decision to use your shield for parries at the start of the turn. You can not Use Shield Defensively on this turn. If you make any attacks with your other hand this turn, you take penalties for Two-Weapon Fighting until the start of your next turn.
Remaining parries

In most situations, a tower shield provides the indicated shield bonus to your Armor Class. As a standard action you can use a tower shield to grant you total cover until the beginning of your next turn. When using a tower shield in this way it is treated as a solid wall for the purpose of attacks targeting you. You gain total cover for attacks from the direction of your shield and no cover for attacks from other directions. The shield does not, however, provide cover against targeted spells; a spellcaster can cast a spell on you by targeting the shield you are holding. You cannot bash with a tower shield, nor can you use your shield hand for anything else.
When employing a tower shield in combat, you take a –2 penalty on attack rolls because of the shield’s encumbrance.
Tower shield defensive stance.

As a standard action you may hide behind your tower shield. When using a tower shield in this way it is treated as a solid wall for the purpose of attacks targeting you. You gain total cover for attacks from the direction of your shield and no cover for attacks from other directions. The shield does not, however, provide cover against targeted spells; a spellcaster can cast a spell on you by targeting the shield you are holding. You cannot bash with a tower shield, nor can you use your shield hand for anything else.

Divine Bond (Shield)

At 5th level, instead of forming a divine bond with her weapon or a mount, a Sacred Shield forms a bond with her shield. As a standard action, a Sacred Shield can enhance her shield by calling on the aid of a celestial spirit. This bond lasts for 1 minute per paladin level. When called, the spirit causes the shield to shed light like a torch.
At 5th level, the spirit grants the shield a +1 enhancement bonus. For every three levels beyond 5th, the shield gains another +1 enhancement bonus, to a maximum of +6 at 20th level. These bonuses can be added to the shield, stacking with existing enhancement bonuses to a maximum of +5.
Alternatively they can be used to add any of the following armor special abilities: arrow deflection, arrow catching, bashing, rallying, determination, fortification (any), reflecting, and spell resistance (any). The reflecting enhancement may be used once each time the sacred shield makes use of her divine bond. Adding these armor special abilities consumes an amount of bonus equal to the property’s cost. These bonuses are added to any properties the shield already has, but duplicate special abilities do not grant any extra benefit. If the shield is not magical, at least a +1 enhancement bonus must be added before any other special abilities can be added. These bonuses disappear if Sacred Shield unequips the shield.
A Sacred Shield can use this ability once per day at 5th level, and one additional time per day for every four levels beyond 5th, to a maximum of four times per day at 17th level.

A barbarian is proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g}, light armor, medium armor, and shields (except tower shields and bucklers).

Cavaliers are proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g}, with all types of armor (heavy, light, and medium) and with shields (except tower shields and bucklers).

Clerics are proficient with all {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}simple weapons{/g}, light armor, medium armor, and shields (except tower shields and bucklers). Clerics are also proficient with the favored weapon of their deities.

Druids are proficient with the following weapons: club, dagger, dart, quarterstaff, scimitar, scythe, sickle, shortspear, sling, and spear. They are also proficient with all {g|Encyclopedia:NaturalAttack}natural attacks{/g} (claw, bite, and so forth) of any form they assume with wild shape.
Druids are proficient with light and medium armor but are prohibited from wearing metal armor; thus, they may wear only padded, leather, or hide armor. A druid may also wear wooden armor that has been altered by the ironwood {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spell{/g} so that it functions as though it were steel. Druids are proficient with shields (except tower shields and bucklers) but must use only wooden ones.
Oracles are proficient with all {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}simple weapons{/g}, light armor, medium armor, and shields (except tower shields and bucklers).

Paladins are proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g}, with all types of armor (heavy, medium, and light), and with shields (except tower shields and bucklers).

A skald is proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g}, light and medium armor, and shields (except tower shields and bucklers). A skald can cast skald {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spells{/g} while wearing light or medium armor and even using a shield without incurring the normal {g|Encyclopedia:Spell_Fail_Chance}arcane spell failure chance{/g}. This does not affect the arcane spell failure chance for arcane spells received from other classes. Like other arcane spellcasters, a skald wearing heavy armor incurs a chance of arcane spell failure if the spell in question has somatic components.

A warpriest is proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g}, as well as the favored weapon of his deity, and with all armor (heavy, light, and medium) and shields (except tower shields and bucklers).

A stalwart defender is proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g} and with all armor (heavy, light, and medium) and shields (including tower shields, but not bucklers).
A beast rider is proficient with light and medium armor, and with shields (with the exception of tower shields and bucklers).
Angelfire apostles are only proficient with light armor.

Debug
Turn this on to have your game log spammed with debug info. You probably want this turned off.
Allow equipping items you aren't profficient with.
As per tabletop rules you can equip armor and weapons even if you are not profficient with it, but recieve penalties to Attack Bonus.
Enable tabletop rules for flanking

In vanilla WotR a target of attack is considered flanked if there is any other unit attacking it disregarding the position of attackers. As per tabletop rules, the flanker must specifically threaten the target from the side opposit to the main attacker. Enable this option to make the game respect tabletop rules. (Minimal angle between attackers required for flanking is set to be 110 degrees. Improved Outflank teamwork feat reduces it to 60.)
Make enemies ignore tabletop flanking rules

If you have enabled tabletop rules for flanking with the option above, you may find the game too easy, because monster's AI didn't get any corresponding changes. By enabling this option you can make the tabletop flanking rules apply only to the player.
Enable Concealment bonus when attacking from behind

Homebrew. When attacking a unit from behind, if this option is enabled and the target doesn't have Blindsight of any kind, the attacker recieves +2 Concealment bonus to Attack. This does not provide any additional benefits related to Concealment.
Enable shield denial when attacking from behind
Homebrew. When attacking a unit from behind, if this option is enabled, the target can't lose its shield to defend and therefore loses its Shield bonus to AC.
Enable concealment when attacking from behind

Homebrew. When attacking a unit from behind, if this option is enabled and the target doesn't have Blindsight of any kind, the attacker is treated as it had the total concealment. This can leave the target flat-footed.
Add Buckler parry

Homebrew. Adds new basic abilities to characters proficient with bucklers. This ability allows to use the buckler in order to parry incoming attacks at the expense of taking two-weapon fighting penalties.
Forbid wielding rapiers in two-hands
By tabletop rules one can not wield rapiers in two hands to add Str modifier *1.5 to damage and attack. Enable this setting to use this ruling.
Allow couching longspears when mounted

Homebrew. Enable this option to bring another benefit to Mounted Combat feat - it will allow the character to wield longspears one-handed when mounted (you may swap handedness through the "Use weapons one-handedly").
Allow equipping two-handed weapons with a buckler

As per tabletop rules you can equip two-handed weapons with a buckler. However you lose your AC bonus from the buckler if you actually use your off-hand for attack. If you are equipping a melee weapon this way, you take -1 penalty to Attack, but not from bows or crossbows (or if you have the Unhindering Shield feat).
Give Immediate Repositioning ability to Tower Shield Specialist archetype

As per tabletop rules, Fighter's archetype Tower Shield Specialist acquires the Immediate Repositioning ability at lvl 13, allowing her turn around with a Swift action without breaking the defensive stance of Tower Shield. Vanilla WotR doesn't have the defensive stance, so this ability was substituted with Total Cover feature. Enable this option to add the Immediate Reposition to the Tower Shield Specialist progression. (This will not affect characters who already have 13 levels in the archetype unless you respec.)
Remove Total Cover Feature from Tower Shield Specialist archetype

As per tabletop rules, Fighter's archetype Tower Shield Specialist acquires the Immediate Repositioning ability at lvl 13, allowing her turn around with a Swift action without breaking the defensive stance of Tower Shield. Vanilla WotR doesn't have the defensive stance, so this ability was substituted with Total Cover feature. Enable this option to remove the Total Cover from the Tower Shield Specialist progression. (This will not affect charcters who already have 13 levels in the archetype unless you respec.)
Enable Soft Cover

As per tabletop rules, if a character performs an attack while there's any other creature on the line of attack, the target recieves Cover bonus to AC depending on the obstacle size. Enable this option to add this rule to the game.
Make Improved Precise Shot feat ignore Soft Cover

As per tabletop rules, Improved Precise Shot allows the character to deny the target AC bonuses coming from any sort of cover. If you enabled Soft Cover rules with the option above, you may enable this option to make corresponding changes to the Improved Precise Shot feat.
Change the Shield Wall feat
Homebrew. Enable to change the Shield Wall teamwork feat. Trades harsher conditions for higher AC bonus.
Buff Sacred Shield

Homebrew. By vanilla rules abilities such as Sacred Shield can't raise the enhancement bonus on the item above +5 and rest of points must be spent on enchantments. Enable this setting to allow Sacred Shield ability to raise the enhancement bonus up to +6.
Remove Buckler Proficiency from several classes

Homebrew. Buckler Proficiency is removed from the Shield Proficiency feat and moved into a feat of its own. Several classes that thematically are not suited for using bucklers now are not proficient with it.
Change the Shield spell
Enable this option to change the type of Shield spell bonus to AC from 'Shield' to 'Untyped', but the spell will not be available to Alchemist class anymore.
Allow to use Shield Bash without the Improved Shield Bash feat

According to tabletop rules, any character equipped with a shield can perform a shield bash (losing shield's bonus to AC until the end of the turn) and may also learn Improved Shield Bash feat to not lose the shield's bonus AC. In the base game it's impossible to perform Shield Bash without the Improved Shield Bash feat. Enable this setting to use tabletop rulings.
Change the "Back to Back" teamwork feat

If you have this option enabled while also having Soft Cover rulings enabled, instead of providing +2 Circumstance bonus to AC against flanking attacks the Back to Back teamwork feature will increase the Soft Cover bonus to AC by 1.5 times when you are benefiting from it; additionally, if you have enabled the option for denying shield bonuses during backstabs, your allies will be able to provide you with their own Shield bonus to AC in such situations when you benefit from Back to Back. However, in order to benefit from it both you and the ally must stand back to back no further than 1 foot from each other. 
 This setting also changes effects of the new teamwork feat Back to Back Improved. While this setting is disabled, Improved version of the feat will only increase the bonus from the basic version of the feat by 2. If this setting is enabled while you also have enabled options that grant the Concealment bonus while backstabbing and/or leave the backstabbed target flat-footed, Back to Back Improved will negate these disadvantages.
